AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: Defendant stopped by border patrol agents on an interstate highway in Texas, owner of the truck, appellant in the current case, with a vehicle that had an apparent heavy load, occupants exhibited suspicious behavior when approached, vehicle was traveling at forty to forty-five miles per hour, contesting the district court's refusal to allow post-verdict discovery through juror depositions, driver of the stopped vehicle, appellant arguing against the use of the Allen charge, seeking post-verdict discovery through juror depositions, defendant in a case where the trial judge denied a motion to interview jurors, stopped on an interstate highway in Texas 115 miles north of the Mexico/United States border, driver of a truck, truck owner with a vehicle having an apparent heavy or overloaded condition, driver of the truck, makes an assertion about the passengers' actions, vehicle was traveling at forty to forty-five miles per hour, appellant appearing to concede the applicability of a rule to her request for post-trial questioning of jurors
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stanley Pruszenski: United States Border Patrol agent with specialized training, served for two years and five months, received training in Spanish, and had limited proficiency
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Alfred Baron: United States Border Patrol agent with specialized training, native Spanish speaker, participated in approximately 150 incidents involving arrests for transporting illegal aliens, served for slightly over three years
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron: Agents who conducted the stop of Garcia's truck, applied the multi-factorial test to determine reasonable suspicion, observed suspicious behavior from occupants, used flashlight to observe vehicle occupants at night, testified about occupants' attempts to hide from the flashlight, had specialized training as border patrol agents, observed a heavily loaded truck with fogged windows
